audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 28 and Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 28 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Up, Up, and Away!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the prefixes un-, re-, and dis-, let’s blend some words using these prefixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.

/paaak/, pack. /uuunnnpaaak/, unpack. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about polymers. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. baking soda <pause>, bowl <pause>, slime <pause>, glue. Look at the slime in the picture. What does slime feel like?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about polymers. The word is appearance. Appearance is the way that someone or something looks.
Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “The Power of Polymers”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about polymers? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "happy." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "happy." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "happy" and the word "unhappy" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Unhappy. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "unhappy" means "not happy."
Listen as I read the following word: "read." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "read." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "read" and the word "reread" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Reread. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "reread" means to "read again."
Listen as I read the following word: "like." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "like." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "like" and the word "dislike" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Dislike. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "dislike" means "the opposite of like."
Practice adding prefixes "un" "re" or "dis" to the following words to see how many new words you can make.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis" and the words: pack, open, agree>

audio.transcription: Now write "un" "re" and "dis" multiple times as you say the sounds for each.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this story is "Reuse It!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Reuse it! This realistic fiction story is about a girl reusing something broken to make something new.

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: discovery. Discovery means “something that has been found.” The discovery of a new insect is exciting to scientists. Name someone from history who made an important discovery.
Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two words that describe Keesha at the beginning of the story.
What discovery does Keesha make in the garage? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How does Keesha reuse the broken mold? Describe the process.
Have you ever reused an old or broken object in a new way? What did you do?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write how you think Keesha’s mom feels about the broken mold at the end of the story. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Add Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Reuse It!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: built, correct, inside, island, language>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word island. Say the word with me. Island. Which sounds do you hear in island? (/i/ /l/ /a/ /n/ /d/). Blend the sounds together.
What letters to you see? (i-s-l-a-n-d) The letter s in island is silent, so we have to remember that when we spell the word.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: built, correct, inside, island, language.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Add Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: low. <slight pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /b/
Add the sound /b/ to the beginning of the word low. What's the new word? <pause> blow
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's add a sound to the end of a word. Listen as I say a word: why. <slight pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /z/
Add the sound /z/ to the end of the word why. What's the new word? <pause> wise
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about clothing fasteners. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. jacket <pause>, zipper <pause>, shirt <pause>, button <pause>, sneaker <pause>, shoelace. Look at the picture of the sneaker. How do you close sneakers?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about clothing fasteners. The word is practical. Practical means “useful or appropriate for use.”
Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “How We Close Our Clothes”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about clothing fasteners? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this text is "Presenting Prefixes.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Presenting Prefixes. This text is a comic about prefixes and how to use them. The photos help readers understand the ideas in captions and speech bubbles.

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: familiar. Familiar means “well known.” This place looks very familiar to me. I think I’ve been here before. What are some familiar sights and sounds in your neighborhood?
Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find Renata’s first example of a word with a prefix.
What does unruly mean? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What are unpaired words? Explain.
Which base words in the text are familiar to you? Which are new to you?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List the examples Renata gives for each prefix. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany one word for each prefix.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "well." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "well." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "well" and the word "unwell" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Unwell. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "unwell" means "not well."
Listen as I read the following word: "build." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "build." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "build" and the word "rebuild" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Rebuild. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "rebuild" means to "build again."
Listen as I read the following word: "trust." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "trust." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "trust" and the word "distrust" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Distrust. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "distrust" means "the opposite of trust."
Practice adding prefixes "un" "re" or "dis" to the following words to see how many new words you can make.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis" and the words: lock, use, believe>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the prefixes un-, re-, and dis-, let’s blend some words using these prefixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: /paaak/, pack. /uuunnnpaaak/, unpack. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether’. Say the word nice and loud.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Presenting Prefixes” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words that begin with un- and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words that begin with un-. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word disappear. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: review/disagree, uncertain/rebuild.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "able." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "able." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "able" and the word "unable" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Unable. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "unable" means "not able."
Listen as I read the following word: "fill." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "fill." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "fill" and the word "refill" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Refill. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "refill" means to "fill again."
Listen as I read the following word: "honest." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "honest." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "honest" and the word "dishonest" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Dishonest. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "dishonest" means "the opposite of honest."

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the prefixes un-, re- and dis-, let’s blend some words using these prefixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with un-.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with re-.
Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word do. <pause> Add re- to the beginning. What word did you make? Redo.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word do <pause>. Now change do to redo. Which sounds are different? Which letters will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: Should I list the letter cards needed to buid the words?

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: oh, person, street, system, warm.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word system. Say the word with me. System. The word "system" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: s-y-s-t-e-m. The letter "y" makes the /i/ sound in the word "system."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: oh, person, street, system, warm.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word distrust.
Now write the word unplug.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: TK>

audio.transcription: regroup
dishonest
unsafe
disappear
reheat
unrest
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Prefixes "un" and "dis" can mean “not” or “the opposite of.” Prefix "re" means "again."
Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this text is "That Rocks!" Point to each word as you read the title with me: That Rocks! This is a comic. Remember to pay attention to the illustrations as well as the words in the speech bubbles. Read the comic. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the all the words in the comic with prefixes un-, re-, and dis- and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.

The first sentence is: We are unable to return to the island this year. Say the sentence with me: We are unable to return to the island this year. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: She is disappointed with her report and will rewrite it. Say the sentence with me: She is disappointed with her report and will rewrite it. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Let's review prefixes. A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It can change the word’s meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "clear." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "clear." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" and the word "clear">

audio.transcription: unclear. <pause> The prefix "un" means “not” or “the opposite of,” therefore, unclear means “not clear.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" and the word "clear", under them, show the word "unclear">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "name." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of the word "name." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" and the word "name">

audio.transcription: rename. <pause> The prefix "re" means “again,” therefore, rename means “name again.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" and the word "name", under them, show the word "rename">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "agree." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "agree." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" and the word "agree">

audio.transcription: disagree. <pause> The prefix "dis" means “not” or “the opposite of,” therefore, disagree means “the opposite of agree.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" and the word "agree", under them, show the word "disagree">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the prefixes un, re, or dis to the following words. Then determine the meaning of each new word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words across from the following phonics/syllable cards: (dis card) grace, (re card) wash, (un card) lucky, (re card) join, (dis card) color, (un card) sealed>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the story “That Rocks!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about gemstones. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. gemstones <pause>, peridotite <pause>, amethyst <pause>, ruby <pause>, opal. Look at the picture of the opal. What colors do you see?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about gemstones. The word is durable. Durable means “able to stay strong and in good condition for a long time.”
Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “What a Gem!”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about gemstones? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this text is "Rocks Tell Earth's Story.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Rocks Tell Earth's Story. You will read an informational text about different kinds of rocks.

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: categories. Categories are groups of similar items within a larger group. The baking contest has three categories: cakes, pies, and cookies. What categories of books can you find at the library?
Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find a word in the Sedimentary Rocks section that begins with the prefix dis-.
How do igneous rocks form? Find the sentences that answer this question.
What are the three categories of rocks? How are they alike and different?
Which facts from the text did you already know? Which facts are new to you?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw three boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write about one type of rock in each box. Use this information to write a one or two sentnece summary of the text. <pause> Share your summary with a partner before writing.

Let's review prefixes "un," "re," and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It can change the word’s meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "load." Add the prefix "un-" to the beginning of "load." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "load" and the phonics/syllable card for "un">

audio.transcription: unload. <pause> The prefix "un" means “not” or “the opposite of,” therefore, unload means “the opposite of load.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "load" and the phonics/syllable card for "un", under them, show the word "unload">

audio.transcription: Now add the prefix "re" to the beginning of the word "load." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "load" and the phonics/syllable card for "re">

audio.transcription: reload. <pause> The prefix "re" means “again,” therefore, reload means “load again.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "load" and the phonics/syllable card for "re", under them, show the word "reload">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "place." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "place." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word place and the phonics/syllable card for "dis">

audio.transcription: displace. <pause> The prefix "dis" means “not” or “the opposite of,” therefore, displace means “the opposite of place.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word place and the phonics/syllable card for "dis", under them, show the word "displace">

audio.transcription: Practice adding the prefixes "un," "re," or "dis" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words across from the following phonics/syllable cards: (re card) trace, (un card) bent, (dis card) grace, (re card) copy, (un card) easy, (re card) fuel>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: untie, rewind, disobey, unclear, replace, unreal, disagree, resell, reset, disable, undo, dishonest. Now look at these two categories. This is the word untie. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put untie under? <pause> Yes, untie goes in the un- category because the word untie begins with un-. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
"Un-" is a common word part. You may notice the un- word part in many words. As we read, let's look for words with un-.

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Rocks Tell Earth’s Story.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: un-tie
Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. un-tie, untie.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: unhappy
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Unhappy, un-hap-py.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with prefixes re-, dis-, or un- and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
Circle all the words with prefixes re-, dis-, or un-. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word unfair. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: unwise/disobey, uncover/reveal.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "do." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "do." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "do" and the word "undo" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Undo. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "undo" means "not do."
Listen as I read the following word: "heat." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "heat." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "heat" and the word "reheat" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Reheat. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "reheat" means to "heat again."
Listen as I read the following word: "honest." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "honest." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "honest" and the word "dishonest" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Dishonest. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "dishonest" means "the opposite of honest."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: built, correct, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word built. Say the word with me: "built"
Spell the word with me: b-u-i-l-t. The word "built" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: correct, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: Should I list the letter cards needed to buid the words?

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. built, <pause> correct, <pause> inside, <pause> island, <pause> language, <pause> oh, <pause> person, <pause> street, <pause> system, <pause> warm.
audio.notes: <visual: show "built, correct, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.

Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "We wear ______ to stay warm when it's cold outside ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "We were [blank] when it's cold outside." Then show "built, correct, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this text is "What's That Rock?" Point to the word as you read the title with me: What's That Rock? This text includes a chart with labels and images.
What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the chart?
Make your own chart that includes at least three categories with illustrated examples.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "do." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "do." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "do" and the word "undo" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Undo. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "undo" means "not do."
Listen as I read the following word: "heat." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "heat." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "heat" and the word "reheat" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Reheat. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "reheat" means to "heat again."
Listen as I read the following word: "trust." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "trust." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "trust" and the word "distrust" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Distrust. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "distrust" means "the opposite of trust."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: built, correct, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word correct. Say the word with me: "correct"
Spell the word with me: c-o-r-r-e-c-t. The word "correct" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: built, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the text “What’s That Rock?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

An abbreviation is a shortened version of a word that frequently ends with a period. Titles, months, and days are often abbreviated, or shortened, in writing. Abbreviations for proper nouns are capitalized.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "October" and the abbreviation "Oct." next to each other>

audio.transcription: Look at the word "October." The abbreviation for "October" is "Oct." The abbreviation "Oct." includes the first few letters of the word, followed by a period.
Some other abbreviations have different patterns, such as "Dr." for the word "Doctor."
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "Doctor" and the abbreviation "Dr." next to it>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces the following abbreviations:
audio.notes: <visual: have two columns, one that shows the full words and one that show the abbreviations for the following words: Missus (Mrs.), April (Apr.), Road (Rd.), Monday (Mon.), Avenue (Ave.)>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about air pressure. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. weather map <pause>, front <pause>, pressure. Look at the picture of the weather map. What do you think the blue and red lines mean?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about air pressure. The word is indicates. Indicates means “shows or points out.”
Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “Weather on the Move”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about air pressure? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "do." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "do." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "do" and the word "undo" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Undo. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "undo" means "not do."
Listen as I read the following word: "heat." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "heat." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "heat" and the word "reheat" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Reheat. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "reheat" means to "heat again."
Listen as I read the following word: "trust." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "trust." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "trust" and the word "distrust" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Distrust. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "distrust" means "the opposite of trust."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with dis-.
Now, let's put a box around all the abbreviations.
Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word form. <pause> Add re- to the beginning. What word did you make? Reform.
audio.notes: <PRODUCTION: Is there and MP4 video modeling this? If not, we need the e-pocket chart here so the teacher can model this>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word form <pause>. Now change form to reform. Which sounds are different? Which letters will be different?

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this story is "Tyler's Party.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Tyler's Party. You will read a story about a boy planning his winter birthday party.
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: satisfied. Satisfied means “pleased.” Dan was satisfied with his performance in the race. When do you feel the most satisfied?
Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that tells what Tyler wants Mom to do with the invitation.
What does Tyler want to do at his birthday party? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why does Tyler smile at the end of the story? Explain.
Would you feel satisfied with cold weather on your birthday? Why or why not?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. <pause> Label the details, such as Mom, Tyler, invitation, ice skating, and party. <pause> Use the drawing to retell the story to a partner. Then, write your retelling.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 29.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Tyler’s Party.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about ocean currents. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. map <pause>, rubber duck <pause>, currents <pause>, rubber ducks <pause>, ocean <pause>, Arctic Ocean <pause>, Pacific Ocean <pause>, Atlantic Ocean. Look at the currents on the map. Where are these currents?
Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about ocean currents. The word is distant. Someone or something that is distant is far away.
Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
Now listen to “Friendly Floatees.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about ocean currents? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review prefixes "un" "re" and "dis." A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. It changes the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "un" "re" and "dis">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "happy." Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of "happy." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "un" across from the word "happy" and the word "unhappy" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Unhappy. <pause> The prefix "un" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "unhappy" means "not happy."
Listen as I read the following word: "read." Add the prefix "re" to the beginning of "read." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "re" across from the word "read" and the word "reread" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Reread. <pause> The prefix "re" means "again." For example, to "reread" means to "read again."
Listen as I read the following word: "like." Add the prefix "dis" to the beginning of "like." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable card for "dis" across from the word "like" and the word "dislike" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Dislike. <pause> The prefix "dis" can mean "not" or "the opposite of." For example, "dislike" means "the opposite of like."
Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word rethink.
Now write the word unplug.
Finally, write this sentence: Please fix the unmade bed and refold the towels.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 29 Student Book. The title of this text is "Water!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Water! This text is a journal entry about water and how it can change.

Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: record. Record means “to write down.” Pedro uses a pen and a notepad to record his dad’s grocery list. Do you prefer to record notes by hand or on a computer?
Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the adjective the writer uses to describe water.
What riddle does the writer record? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How does the diagram support the main text of the journal entry? Explain.
What questions about water do you still have? How can you find the answers?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write another journal entry from the writer’s perspective about water. <pause> Share your pictures and articles with a partner.
Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 29, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 23.
audio.notes: <visual:

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 29 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Water!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
audio.notes: <visual: empty word ladder with 6 rungs>

audio.transcription: This word means “not clean.”
Change the base word of unclean to form a word that means “different from or not like something.”
Change the prefix of unlike to name the opposite of like.
Change the base word of dislike to name what you do when you end a call.
Change the prefix of disconnect to form a word that means “connect again”.
Change the base word of reconnect to form a word that means “start again.”
Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 29!
Let's review abbreviations. "street" <pause> "St." An abbreviation is a shortened version of a word that frequently ends with a period.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "street" and the abbreviation "St." next to each other>

audio.transcription: Build the abbreviations for the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "Mister," "Lane," "November," "Wednesday," "Boulevard," "Professor">

audio.transcription: Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: built, correct, inside, island, language, oh, person, street, system, warm>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "inside."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: inside>

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: day
Say the word day, but change the beginning sound. Change /d/, to /m/. What's the new word? <pause> may
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: send
Say the word send, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> sent
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: man
Say the word man, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ā/. What's the new word? <pause> main
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
